isis.stitle: 7.3 Liter Diesel Engine Service (1991) - CONNECTING RODS, PISTONS AND RINGS - CONNECTING RODS, PISTONS AND RINGS (Reconditioning) - Inspection

step1.para: Visually inspect the pistons for scuffed or scored skirts, cracked or worn ring lands and cracked or scuffed pin bores, discarding any showing such condition.

Piston pins should be inspected and measured for wear. If piston pins show signs of corrosion or etching or are not within specifications, they should be replaced with new pins. See "SPECIFICATIONS". Piston assemblies furnished for service replacement are complete with piston pins accurately fitted.
If pistons require replacement, a standard or oversize piston must be chosen as follows:

step2.para:
Measure cylinder bore diameters using a telescoping gauge with outside micrometer or dial bore gauge to determine cylinder out-of-round and taper, Figure 5.19
.
Repeat measurements at the "Top" and at the "Bottom" of ring travel. Record the readings and calculate the difference.
The out-of-round condition at the top and bottom of ring travel is the difference between the "Top" reading and "Bottom" reading for each set of measurements.

note.para: Refer to "SPECIFICATIONS" for maximum out-of-round and cylinder bore taper.

figure.caption: Figure 5.19 Checking Cylinder Bore Using Dial Bore Gauge (At Top of Ring Travel)
Figure 5.20 Checking Cylinder for Out-of-Round and Taper (Dial Indicator Shown At Bottom of Ring Travel)

step2.para: If taper and out-of-round for cylinder walls are within specifications use new standard size service pistons.

If cylinder bores exceed out-of-round and/or taper specifications reboring may be required as described in Section 6. Such cylinder bore reconditioning will require the use of oversize service pistons. In addition to the standard size service piston 0.010 in., 0.020 in. and 0.030 in. oversize pistons are available. Verify piston size by measuring skirt diameter ( Figure 5.22
).

important.para: THE SIZE PISTON SELECTED SHOULD BE LARGE ENOUGH TO PERMIT CLEANING UP THE CYLINDER BORE AND PROVIDE THE PROPER RUNNING CLEARANCE IN THE CYLINDER BORE. REFER TO "SPECIFICATIONS".

step1.para: For detailed procedures on reboring the cylinder bore refer to "CRANKSHAFT, MAIN BEARINGS, FLYWHEEL AND CRANKCASE".

note.para: Faulty rings cannot always be detected by visual inspection. Therefore, whenever a piston is removed from a cylinder, it is recommended that the piston rings be replaced.

step1.para: Visually inspect NEW rings for cleanliness.
Prior to installing the rings on the piston, check each ring for proper gap as follows:

step2.para: Push the ring down into the cylinder bore making sure the ring is square with the cylinder wall.

Measure the gap between the ends of each ring with a feeler gauge as shown in Figure 5.23
.
If the gap does not meet the "SPECIFICATIONS", select another ring.

note.para: Piston rings are available for service in standard sizes as well as 0.010 in., 0.020 in. and 0.030 in. oversize piston rings. Each ring should be fitted and checked in the cylinder in which it is to be used. Mark accordingly so they are installed in their respective bores.

figure.caption: Figure 5.22 Piston Skirt Dia. Measurement (90° to pin bore)

step1.para: Check side clearance of piston rings in the groove of the piston on which they are to be installed, as follows:

step2.para:
Place the outer edge of the ring in the piston groove ( Figure 5.24
).
Roll the ring, in its respective groove, entirely around the piston. Make sure the ring is "free" in the groove.

With a feeler gauge ( Figure 5.24
) check the side clearance of each ring in its respective groove. (See "SPECIFICATIONS".)

step1.para: Measure inside diameter of piston pin bushing in connecting rod using a telescoping gauge and a micrometer, Figure 5.24. (See "SPECIFICATIONS". If bushings are worn, new bushing must be installed after connecting rod passes inspection.

Remove any worn bushing using Connecting Rod Bushing Remover and Installer Tool ZTSE4154. Place connecting rod under a hydraulic press in line with the properly sized hole on the support block and use ZTSE4154 to press out the bushing, Figure 5.26
.

figure.caption: Figure 5.24 Checking Ring-to-Groove Side Clearance with Feeler Gauge
Figure 5.25 Checking Connecting Rod Piston Pin Bushing I.D.
Figure 5.26 Using ZTSE-4154 Tool to Remove Worn Connecting Rod Bushing

step1.para:
Clean the connecting rod thoroughly and visually inspect for defects. Using telescoping gauge and a micrometer, check connecting rod piston pin bushing bore diameter, Figure 5.27
. (See "SPECIFICATIONS".) Replace as required.
Continue connecting rod inspection (crankshaft end) as follows:

step2.para:
Measure connecting rod bearing bore diameter (with bearing inserts removed), Figure 5.28. (See "SPECIFICATIONS")
for bearing bore I.D.

note.para: Measure bore diameter with connecting rod nut tightened to specified special torque. Replace as required.

step2.para:
With connecting rod assembled and rod bolts and nuts tightened to specified special torque use a dial bore gauge indicator to measure out-of-round, Figure 5.29
(see "SPECIFICATIONS"). Replace rod if maximum out-of-round specification is exceeded.

figure.caption: Figure 5.27 Checking Connecting Rod Piston Pin Bushing Bore Diameter
Figure 5.28 Measuring Connecting Rod Bearing Bore Diameter
Figure 5.29 Measuring Connecting Rod Bearing Bore Roundness

step2.para:
Measure connecting rod bore taper ( Figure 5.30
), by measuring the bore I. D. near the large chamfer, record reading and measure the bore I.D. near the small chamfer, record reading. The difference between the two readings is the bore taper. (See "SPECIFICATIONS"). Replace rod if maximum bore taper is exceeded.

With connecting rod cap removed, visually inspect the surface finish of the connecting rod bearing bore. The bore must be smooth and free of scoring or nicks, Figure 5.31
. Replace as required.

note.para: Connecting rod inspection (4a-d) can be made using accurate bore gauging instruments. Refer to instructions included with the gauges.

step2.para: CONNECTING ROD BEND AND TWIST

step1.para: An engine component wear pattern can be identified and used to diagnose a problem. Common examples of connecting rod wear pattern diagnostic clues are presented as follows:

step2.para: A shiny surface on edge of piston pin bushing usually indicates that a connecting rod is bent or piston pin hole is not in proper relation to piston skirt and ring grooves.
Abnormal connecting rod bearing wear can be caused by either a bent connecting rod, an improperly machined journal, or a tapered connecting rod bore.

Twisted connecting rods will not create an easily identifiable wear pattern, but badly twisted rods will disturb action of entire piston, rings, and connecting rod assembly and may be the cause of excessive oil consumption.

important.para: IF THE CONNECTING RODS DO NOT MEET THE REQUIREMENTS SET FORTH IN PARAGRAPHS 1-6 "CONNECTING ROD INSPECTION", REPLACE THE ENTIRE CONNECTING ROD ASSEMBLY.
